How should I manage a person with a suspected learning disability?
subChapters.htmlHeader: How should I manage a person with a suspected learning disability?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
Note: Where a learning disability is suspected assess the person's capacity to make decisions throughout assessment, care, and treatment on a decision-by-decision basis, and be mindful of their communication needs.

  • If a learning disability is suspected, offer a referral to the local community learning disability service/team for confirmation of the diagnosis and general management. Depending on local availability, this may incorporate specialist assessment, support, and intervention services, delivered by psychologists, psychiatrists, behavioural analysts, nurses, social care staff, speech and language therapists, educational staff, occupational therapists, physiotherapists, physicians, paediatricians, and pharmacists. 
  • Additionally:
    • Referral to a clinical psychologist may be necessary if the person requires assessment for purposes such as accessing benefits, determining mental capacity, and/or determining fitness to plead within the criminal justice system. Note: this can be a direct referral or may be made via the community learning disability service/team depending on urgency.
    • Referral to mental health services (either child and adolescent or adult depending on the person's age) may be indicated if mental health problems have been noted. For further information, see the section on behaviour that challenges and mental health problems.
    • Referral to clinical genetics may be indicated if a chromosomal or genetic syndrome is suspected. If a teratogenic exposure has been reported, referral to a clinical geneticist is also advised to rule out an underlying genetic cause that may contribute to or explain the condition.
    • A safeguarding referral in-line with local procedures may be needed if there are concerns regarding maltreatment or exploitation, or if the person is in contact with the criminal justice system.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
The advice to refer people with a suspected learning disability to the local learning disability support team for confirmation and initial management is based on information about the roles of local learning disability support teams provided in the National Institute of Health and Care Excellence (NICE) guideline Mental health problems in people with learning disabilities: prevention, assessment and management [NICE, 2016a], as well as information from numerous local learning disability support teams located across the UK [Dorset NHS Foundation Trust, 2018], [Homerton University Hospital, 2018], [Humber NHS Foundation Trust, 2018], [Northumbria Healthcare, 2018].

Referral to a clinical psychologist
  • The potential reasons for assessment by a clinical psychologist are outlined in the British Psychological Society's Guidance on the Assessment and Diagnosis of Intellectual Disabilities in Adulthood [British Psychological Society, 2015]. The advice that the referral can be direct from primary care or via the learning disability support team depending on urgency is pragmatic, based on what CKS considers to be good medical practice.
Referral to clinical genetics
  • The advice to refer people with suspected genetic or chromosomal disorders to a clinical geneticist is pragmatic, based on what CKS considers to be good medical practice. The advice to refer people with a suspected or confirmed teratogenic exposure to rule out an underlying genetic diagnosis is based on expert opinion from the UK Teratology Information Service relating to Fetal Valproate Syndrome [UKTIS, 2018], and within a publication describing chromosomal abnormalities that phenocopy fetal alcohol syndrome [Douzgou et al, 2012].
